Authors:
Naoko ISHIKAWA, Hajime IKEDA, Tingshuang Yi, Eriko
Takabe-Ito, Hiroshi OKADA, Hirokazu Tsukaya
Title:
Lineage diversifications and hybridizations among Cayratia
japonica and Cayratia tenuifolia species complex
Keywords:
Cryptic species complex; Asia; Australia; Tertiary;
Triploid; Hybridization
Abstract:
Cayratia japonica-C. tenuifolia species complex (Vitaceae)
is distributed from temperate to tropical area of E Asia and
Australasia. Previous phylogenetic analysis of Japanese accessions by
using nuclear-encoded single-copy AS1 suggested presence of three
distinct lineages and hybridizations among them. The analysis also
predicted that the diversifications occurred at the continental Asia,
not in Japan. In this study, phylogenetic analysis was conducted using
AS1 and chloroplast (cp) DNA (trnL-F and trnC-petN) to reveal details of
the diversifications and hybridizations in the entire C. japonica-C.
tenuifolia species complex, covering wide area of the distribution. The
analyses revealed that 1) Accessions from Australia and Asia formed
distinct monophyletic clades in both AS1 and cpDNA tree. 2) Although
several differences were found in topology and resolution between AS1
and cpDNA tree within the Asian clade, the results were largely
consistent with each other. 3) In cpDNA tree, two diversifications
corresponding to their distributions were found and estimated to be
occurred in Tertiary. 4) AS1 analysis revealed existence of seven
lineages in Asian clade, and occurrences of inter-lineage hybridizations
among four lineages. 5) The Asian lineages are morphologically cryptic.
The above results show a complex history of diversification and
hybridizations among the lineages of C. japonica-C. tenuifolia species
complex. This study provides useful data for understanding not only
evolution of species complex but also lineage divergences in Tertiary E
Asia.
